attributes.title: Perceived economic inequality in everyday life and dehumanization
attributes.description: This is a preregistration of an experimental study in which we manipulate the perceived economic inequality (low vs high) in order to see its effect on the tendency to dehumanice the poor and the rich.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Perceived economic inequality in everyday life and dehumanization: Experimental study

sample.value: We compute sample size for a small effect size (Repeated MANCOVA, f = .15, α = .05, 80% Power, Faul, Erdfelder, Buchner & Lang, 2009). G- power analysis indicates that a minimum of 194 participants are required.

analyses.value: We will conduct simple statistics, t-test, and MANCOVA analysis in order to compare the humanity ascribed to the poor and rich groups (within-subject factors) as a function of the low vs. high level of economic inequality (between-subject factors), controlling by participant’s socioeconomic status.

dependent.value:
Blatant dehumanization. Participants will rate the extend they consider that the poor and the rich groups within the fictitious society are considered as being less (animal-like) or more (human-like) evolved, by using a single slider for each group that goes from 0 (least evolved) to 100 (most evolved). As in the original procedure, in which the blatant measure of dehumanization has previously used (Kteily, Bruneau, Waytz, & Cotterill, 2015), some filler groups were included (e.g., immigrants, entrepreneurs) to cover up the aim of the study. 

Covariates.  We will use the 10-step ladder that measure subjective socioeconomic status (Adler, Epel, Castellazzo, & Ickovics, 2000).

Demographic information (gender, age, and nationality) will be also provided.

conditions.value:
Participants will be invited to imagine that they will settle down in a new neighborhood within a new society.  They will be told that they need to make some decisions (e.g., purchase a house, a car, and a vacation destination) and to familiarize themselves with the locations of the area. So, they can start their new life as a middle-class individual in this place (see Jetten, Molds, & Postmes, 2015). Once we had introduced participants to the study, they were randomly assigned to one condition in which they were presented with the socioeconomic structure that encompasses the society. Following previous procedures (e.g., Sánchez‐Rodríguez, Willis, Jetten, & Rodríguez‐Bailón, 2019), we manipulate the distance between the socioeconomic groups (three groups from poorest to wealthiest) based on the experimental conditions: 

In the low perceived economic inequality, the distribution of income between the socioeconomic group 3 (poorest: earns 30,000 Mazimba Dollars per month), the group 2 (middle income: 40,000 M$/month) and the group 1 (wealthiest: 40,000 M$/month) was equally distributed; while in the high perceived economic inequality, the distribution of income between the socioeconomic group 3 (5,000 M$/month), the group 2 (40,000 M$/month) and the group 1 (150,000 M$/month) was unequally distributed.

To reinforce the material differences between socioeconomics groups, participants will be presented with a selection of cars, houses and vacation destinations that they need to purchase in order to start their new life, with information of their neighbors from different socioeconomic groups, and also they will be presented with pictures of restaurants, parks, grocery stores and imagines of the neighborhood streets. These resources or locations were different based on the experimental conditions.

hypothesis.value: In this experimental study, we aim to confirm the influence that the perceived economic inequality in the everyday context exerts on the perceived humanity gap between poor and rich groups. In this sense, we expected that higher (vs. lower) perceived economic inequality in the everyday context will increase the tendency to dehumanize the poor (Hypothesis 1) and to humanize the rich (Hypothesis 2).

attributes.title: Application of Tukey’s Test for Statistical Measurement of Percentage Indexes Derived from the Difference Between Predicted Crystallographic Data in Five NiTiHf Alloys Obtained by Two Processes
attributes.description: The present paper uses the Tukey test to measure the minimal significative difference (MSD) between crystallographic data predicted by non-linear mathematical models generated from graphics published by Zarinejad (2008) and Potapov (1997) on 5 nominal compositions of Ni50Ti50-XHfX .at% substitutional alloys fused by arc melting and melt spinning processes. Results show that the calculated MSD do not represent a statistically significant difference. Therefore, it is concluded that the independent variable (Hafnium content) does not change the analysed dependent variables (lattice parameters, crystalline structure, volume and monoclinic angle β) for any fusing processes.

summary.value: O artigo foi publicado oficialmente no periódico IJERT e listado no seguindo link: https://www.ijert.org/volume-09-issue-03-march-2020

attributes.title: ExPra: Team im Leben, Team im Stress
attributes.description: We will measure jealousy before and after recalling a memory in their current partnership by asking them to write about it in detail. Participants will be divided into four groups and will either write about a situation with jealousy, a situation in which feelings of jealousy were discussed/solved, a situation with exclusion by partner or their last positive experience in the partnership. Our purpose is to find out if remembering a specific situation can cause jealousy.

q1.value: Araniya Girupagaran, Nuria Hilfiker, Michelle Rahm, Benedicta Mohr

q2.value:
H1: The jealousy score in the experimental condition "situation with jealousy" will be higher after the experimental induction than before. 
H2: The jealousy score will increase more in the experimental condition "situation with jealousy" than in the condition "situation in which feelings of jealousy were discussed/solved". 
H3: The jealousy score will increase more in the experimental condition "situation with jealousy" than in the condition "situation with exclusion".
H4: The jealousy score will increase more in the experimental condition "situation with jealousy" than in the control condition "last positive experience in the partnership"

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: It is a mixed design with repeated measures.  The Between subject variable are the four conditions (situation with jealousy, situation in which feelings of jealousy were discussed/solved, situation with exclusion and last positive experience in the partnership). The Within subject variable are the pre (before recalling the situation) and post (after recalling the situation) measures of the jealousy score.

q7.value: It will be a block randomization and Unipark will do it for us. Each participants will be randomly assigned to one of the four equally sized, predetermined blocks (=conditions).

q8.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through the psychology mailing list, social media and through the authors of this study and three other studies, who will us the same sample . Participants must be at least 18 years old and at least 6 months in a heterosexual relationship. Participants will have a chance to win two cinema vouchers and psychology students can earn one "Versuchspersonenstunde".

q11.value: Our target sample size is 128 participants. The target sample size of our study was 84 to achieve enough power, but another project team, who will use the same sample as us, need 128 participants.

q12.value: We used the software program G*Power to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .8 power to detect a an effect size .4 at the standard .05 alpha error probability.

q13.value: We will terminate our data collection, when we have recruited 128 participants.

question.value: We manipulated the situation the participants have to recall or imagine, if they never experienced such situation. It will either be a situation with jealousy, situation in which feelings of jealousy were discussed/solved, situation with exclusion by the partner or last positiv experience in the partnership.

We will measure jealousy by asking them, how jealous they feel, which will be answered on a scale of 1-5, 1 being „not at all“, 5 being „very much“. This item will be integrated in the PANAS. We will also measure socio-demographic information (e.g. age, sex, duration of the relationship), relationship satisfaction with the Relationship Assessment Scale, Jealousy trait with „Vertrauen und Eifersucht bei Paaren“, communication quality with KOMQUAL, affect with PANAS, self-esteem, feeling of control and attachment with relationship questionnaire. We will only analyze the jealousy item.

We will use a Wilcoxon Test to analyze our data. We will compare the pre post scores of each condition. If the there is an significant difference between the pre and post score, we will compare it with another condition, the difference of which is also signifikant.

q18.value: The jealousy score does not require any additional transformations.

q19.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the Wilcoxon Test suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct.

q20.value: We will verify that each subject answered the jealousy item. Outliers will be included in the analysis.

q21.value: If a subject does not complete the jealousy item, that subject will not be included in the analysis.

q23.value: The link to our previous preregistration: https://osf.io/cykm4

attributes.title: Do Liberals Think More WEIRD? Toward an understanding of the relationship between holism and political ideology

q1.value: Do Liberals Think More WEIRD? Toward an understanding of the relationship between holistic thinking and political ideology-II

q2.value: Rüya Su Şencan, Selahattin Adil Saribay, Mertcan Güngör

q3.value: Previous studies showed that analytic/holistic thinking styles-measured by the Triad Task- are related to political ideology (Talhelm et al., 2015; Talhelm, 2018); liberals tend to think analytically and conservatives holistically. Our first pre-registered study did not reveal solid evidence for this relationship. On the contrary, it revealed that some aspects of holistic thinking (Expectation of Change and Tolerance for Contradictions, which we called "dialecticism" for practical purposes) are positively related to social and–unexpectedly—economic liberalism.  The current study aims first to (1) replicate the Triad Task-social conservatism relation with methodological improvements on our first study, (2) replicate the other findings from our first study on the dialecticism-liberalism relation, and (3) investigate the potential mechanisms underlying these effects in a high-powered study.

q4.value:
H1: When holism is operationalized via the Triad Task, it will be positively related to social conservatism as in the previous studies (Talhelm et al., 2015; Talhelm, 2018).
H2: No relationship is expected between the responses on the Triad Task and economic conservatism.
H3a: When holism is operationalized via dialecticism (i.e., Tolerance of Contradiction and Expectation of Change), it will be negatively related to social conservatism.
H3b: When holism is operationalized via dialecticism, it will be negatively related to economic conservatism.
H4a: Analytic (taxonomic) responses on the Triad Task will be positively related to Type 2 processes (measured by the CRT)
H4b: If H4a is supported, the engagement of Type 2 processing (CRT) will account more variance than cultural thought style measured by the Analysis-Holism Scale (AHS; Choi, Koo & Choi, 2007) in the relationship between holistic thinking (measured by the Triad Task) and social conservatism.
H5: Dialecticism will be positively correlated with ambiguity tolerance.
H6: Ambiguity tolerance will account for a statistically significant amount of the variance in the negative relationship between social conservatism and dialecticism. That is to say, when ambiguity tolerance increases, dialecticism increases, and social conservatism decreases.
H7: Dialecticism measured by the Proverb Task will be positively correlated with holistic thinking scores on the AHS. 
H8a: Dialecticism measured by the Proverb Task will be negatively correlated with social conservatism. 
H8b: Dialecticism measured by the Proverb Task will be negatively correlated with economic conservatism. 
H9: Economic conservatism will negatively correlate with collectivism.
H10: If H9 is true, we expect that collectivism will account for a statistically significant amount of variance in economic conservatism-dialecticism relation. That is to say, when collectivism increases, dialecticism increases, and economic conservatism decreases.
H11: We expect that, compared to rural populations, in urban populations, the relationship between cultural thought style and political orientation will be more pronounced, as previous research suggested (Talhelm et al., 2015; Talhelm, 2018).

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We have a correlational research design.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be recruited through a web link posted on Bogazici University student groups on social media. Participation will be compensated by right to participate in a lottery by which 250 TL gift vouchers will be given to 3 participants. All participants will be older than 18 years old and native Turkish speakers. 

If we cannot reach the attempted number of participants in this way, we will send the survey link to students enrolled in introductory psychology courses. 

As a last resort, we will share the survey link on our personal accounts and collect additional data from community sample.

q13.value: A total sample size of 743 is aimed for the study. However, as the data will be collected online, the number of incomplete surveys and random responders are expected to be high. Thus, we will continue to collect data until we obtain 743 participants who completed the study and correctly answered the two attention check questions.

q14.value: We determined the smallest effect size of interest as the smallest effect observed in the previous studies investigating the same effect (Talhelm et al., 2015; Talhelm, 2018), which was r = .12 (Study 1 in Talhelm, 2018). We estimated that 743 participants would be required to achieve .95 power given this effect size, for one-tail testing at .05 significance level.

question.value:
Cultural thought style will be assessed by three different measures. 

First, a modified version of the TCT (Ji, Zhang, & Nisbett, 2004). Modifications were done based on a pilot study (N = 62) according to which each triad was selected while making sure that both the taxonomic and thematic relations can be recognized by the majority, that taxonomically related items do not also connote any thematic relations and that thematically bound items are not perceived as examples of the same category in any sense. Pictures of the selected triads were standardized, paying attention to prevent any two items in a triad from being visually similar to influence response patterns. All pictures were transformed into monochrome. Participants will be presented with one target item and two other items -one taxonomically and the other thematically related to the target- and be asked to choose the one which is most closely related to the target item. Taxonomic pairings are associated with an analytic thinking style and thematic pairings with holistic thinking style. 

Second, a proverb task (Peng & Nisbett, 1999) will be used to assess preferences for dialectical versus non-dialectical proverbs. The proverbs were selected among the ones used by Peng and Nisbett (1999), by Friedman, Chen, and Vid (2006) and additional Turkish proverbs which emphasize dialecticism/non-dialecticism. The selection was made based on content (whether the emphasis on dialecticism or its opposite is clear enough) by three independent coders. For each proverb, ratings of familiarity, frequency of use and poeticality will be used as control variables. In this task consisting of 16 proverbs (8 dialectical), participants will be asked to rate how much they like each proverb and how much they agree with each proverb on a 7-point scale. Proverb lists used in our first study and that will be used in this study can be found in the Files section of the project.

Finally, the Analysis-Holism Scale (AHS; Choi, Koo, & Choi, 2007) as a self-report measure for cultural thought styles will be administered. The AHS consists of four subscales (causality, attitude toward contradiction, perception of change and locus of attention) with 6 items each on a 7-point Likert-type scale (1 = completely disagree, 7 = completely agree). We will use the version we used in our first study, with additional items we wrote.

In order to test the proposed relationship between holistic thinking and other cognitive variables previously studied in political psychology literature, the Multiple Stimulus Types Ambiguity Tolerance Scale-II (MSTAT-II; McLain, 2009) will be given. This scale is a 7-point Likert-type scale consisting of 13 items.

To test the presumptive trifold relationship between holism, collectivism, and
economic liberalism, the Relational-Interdependent Self-Construal (RISC; Cross, Bacon & Morris, 2000) Scale—previously translated and validated in Turkish (Öztürk, Gökoğlu, & Karagonlar, 2015)—will be included. 

To measure analytic cognitive style as defined by the dual process model of the mind, we will use two versions of the Cognitive Reflection Test (CRT-I and CRT-II; Frederick, 2005; Thomson & Oppenheimer, 2016). The first consists of 3 and the second 4 logic questions and score on these tests are calculated by the total number of correct responses. 

Political ideology will be measured by a version of the Scale of Social Conservatism -originally created by Henningham (1996) for the Australian culture and adapted to American culture by Piazza and Landy (2013)- revised by Yılmaz and Sarıbay (2016) to adapt to Turkish politics. The scale consists of 14 items each concerning a social issue (legalization of marijuana, gay marriage etc.) to which responses range from -5 (strongly against) to +5 (not at all against). 

Economic conservatism will be measured by the Economic Conservatism Scale originated by Yılmaz and Sarıbay (2016), consisting of 16 items on a 7-point scale (1 = completely disagree, 7 = completely agree). Sample items are "The government should not interfere in the economics" and "The government should collect higher taxes from the rich and lower taxes from the poor to reduce income equality". 

Finally, in demographic form, participants will be asked several demographic questions such as their gender, age, ethnicity, education, socioeconomic status (SES), hometown, hometown size, religious affiliation, and religiosity. SES will be measured by the MacArthur Scale of Subjective Social Status (Adler, Epel, Castellazzo, & Ickovics, 2000) in which participants are asked to indicate their relative place in the society on an image of a ladder of 10 steps. Religiosity will be measured by single item asking participants the extent to which they feel religious on a scale of 1 (not at all religious) to 7 (highly religious). Also, political ideology will be measured by a single item scale ranging from 1 (very liberal) to 7 (very conservative). 

In addition, we have 2 attention check questions ("Please respond to this question as "I completely disagree" and "I have never drunk water in my life"), one within the AHS and the other in the Economic Conservatism Scale.

We will use the combination of CRT and CRT-2 scores (the sum of the correct responses to the two) as the main measure of analytic cognitive style. We will also conduct analyses with separate CRT and CRT-2 scores and with average scores instead of the sum (to avoid potential bias resulting from the unanswered questions), to check whether the results change.  

We will calculate the holistic thinking score by extracting the number of taxonomic pairings from the number of thematic pairings in the TCT. We will use this score in the correlational analyses involving the TCT. 

For the dialecticism score, we will use the combination of the revised Change subscale (original and added items) and the new Contradiction subscale (only added items emphasizing Tolerance of Contradictions) of the AHS.

In the Proverb Task, in addition to liking rates which previous research used (Peng & Nisbett, 1999), we will also use the ratings of agreement with each proverb. As liking rates can be affected by lots of other things that we cannot control, we think that agreement might provide more reliable results.

All the analyses involving the TCT will be conducted both with the traditional scoring and binomial-linked generalized linear model (see Talhelm et al. 2015; Talhelm, 2018). 

The relationship between the performance on the Triad Task and social and economic conservatism will be analyzed with separate correlations and binomial-linked GLMs. These analysis will be conducted using both the scales for social and economic conservatism and the single item political orientation scale (H1 & H2).

As H2 predicts "no relationship", an equivalence test will be conducted for the correlation between holism measured by the Triad Task and economic conservatism.

The correlation between scores on the combined dialecticism subscale of the AHS and social and economic conservatism will be examined (H3a & H3b). 

Relationship between the CRT scores and holism measured by the Triad Task will be analyzed with correlation and binomial-linked GLM (H4a).

Hierarchical regression models will be tested to investigate how much of the variance in the relationship between the Triad Task scores and conservatism is accounted for by the AHS and the CRT. It is hypothesized that the variance accounted for by the CRT scores will be larger than that by the AHS scores in the relationship between the holism scores from the Triad Task and social conservatism (H4b). 

Correlational analysis will be conducted between ambiguity tolerance (MSTAT-II) and dialecticism (H5).

Hierarchical regressions will be conducted with the combined dialecticism subscale of the AHS as the outcome and the social conservatism as the predictor in the first step, and scores on the MSTAT-II as the predictor in the second step. If the relationship between the dialecticism and conservatism can be explained by ambiguity tolerance as we hypothesized, the scores on the MSTAT-II should account for a statistically significant amount of variance explained by conservatism (H6). 

We will check the partial correlation between the liking rates for dialectical proverbs and scores on the combined dialecticism subscale of the AHS controlling for the liking rates for non-dialectical proverbs, ratings of familiarity, poeticality, and the frequency of use (H7). If the proverb task measures dialectical thinking tendency, proverb ratings should correlate with AHS scores. If so, we will conduct the same analysis with social (H8a) and economic conservatism (H8b) as the outcome instead of AHS scores. 

For the economic conservatism, two additional correlational analyses will be conducted. First, we will examine whether economic liberalism is related to collectivism as suggested above (H9). For this purpose, a correlational analysis will be conducted between economic conservatism and RISC scores. If the expected relationship is observed, we will check the partial correlation between dialecticism and economic conservatism controlling for the RISC scores (H10). 

The relationship between the holistic scores on the Triad Task and social conservatism will also be analyzed separately for participants raised in urban and rural settlements. We will categorize settlements as urban and rural based on the newly included “hometown” item which asks directly where each participant is from, as well as the hometown size question used in the first study. Hence, we will use three different criteria for urban-rural distinction: (1) Categorizing “metropolis” as urban and the rest as rural based on the hometown size question, (2) population size, and (3) population density based on the open-ended hometown question relying on the data obtained from Turkish Statistical Institute (TÜİK). Criteria 2 and 3 will be treated as continuous moderators (H11). 


Analyses examining the relationship between thought styles (analytic vs. holistic) and political orientation will also be conducted controlling for age, gender, childhood SES, religiosity and hometown size.

q21.value: We will use α = .05. We will use one-tailed tests for H1, H3a, H3b, H4a, H5, H7, H8a, H8b, and H9.

q22.value: Participants who do not complete the survey and who give the incorrect response to any of the two attention check questions will be excluded from the analyses.

q23.value: There will be no missing data as only data from participants with complete responses will be analyzed.

q24.value:
To examine holism as a latent construct, we will conduct a SEM analysis. We will include 5 subscales of the AHS (2 for Contradiction: the original Midway items and the newly added Tolerance of Contradictions items), the Proverb Task, and The Triad Task as the indicators of holism. 

Also, to investigate the possibility that taxonomic responses on the Triad Task take more effort than thematic responses (thus, associated with reflective thinking), response times for taxonomic and thematic responses will be compared. Dependent samples t-test will be conducted on participants' average response times for their taxonomic and thematic responses.

q25.value:
References

Adler, N. E., Epel, E. S., Castellazzo, G., & Ickovics, J. R. (2000). Relationship of subjective and objective social status with psychological and physiological functioning: Preliminary data in healthy, White women. Health Psychology, 19(6), 586.

Choi, I., Koo, M., & Choi. (2007). Individual differences in analytic versus holistic thinking. Personality & Social Psychology Bulletin, 33(5), 691–705.

Cross, S. E., Bacon, P. L., & Morris, M. L. (2000). The relational-interdependent self-construal and relationships. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 78(4), 791-808.

registration_responses.q1: Do Liberals Think More WEIRD? Toward an understanding of the relationship between holistic thinking and political ideology-II
registration_responses.q2: Rüya Su Şencan, Selahattin Adil Saribay, Mertcan Güngör
registration_responses.q3: Previous studies showed that analytic/holistic thinking styles-measured by the Triad Task- are related to political ideology (Talhelm et al., 2015; Talhelm, 2018); liberals tend to think analytically and conservatives holistically. Our first pre-registered study did not reveal solid evidence for this relationship. On the contrary, it revealed that some aspects of holistic thinking (Expectation of Change and Tolerance for Contradictions, which we called "dialecticism" for practical purposes) are positively related to social and–unexpectedly—economic liberalism.  The current study aims first to (1) replicate the Triad Task-social conservatism relation with methodological improvements on our first study, (2) replicate the other findings from our first study on the dialecticism-liberalism relation, and (3) investigate the potential mechanisms underlying these effects in a high-powered study.
registration_responses.q4:
H1: When holism is operationalized via the Triad Task, it will be positively related to social conservatism as in the previous studies (Talhelm et al., 2015; Talhelm, 2018).
H2: No relationship is expected between the responses on the Triad Task and economic conservatism.
H3a: When holism is operationalized via dialecticism (i.e., Tolerance of Contradiction and Expectation of Change), it will be negatively related to social conservatism.
H3b: When holism is operationalized via dialecticism, it will be negatively related to economic conservatism.
H4a: Analytic (taxonomic) responses on the Triad Task will be positively related to Type 2 processes (measured by the CRT)
H4b: If H4a is supported, the engagement of Type 2 processing (CRT) will account more variance than cultural thought style measured by the Analysis-Holism Scale (AHS; Choi, Koo & Choi, 2007) in the relationship between holistic thinking (measured by the Triad Task) and social conservatism.
H5: Dialecticism will be positively correlated with ambiguity tolerance.
H6: Ambiguity tolerance will account for a statistically significant amount of the variance in the negative relationship between social conservatism and dialecticism. That is to say, when ambiguity tolerance increases, dialecticism increases, and social conservatism decreases.
H7: Dialecticism measured by the Proverb Task will be positively correlated with holistic thinking scores on the AHS. 
H8a: Dialecticism measured by the Proverb Task will be negatively correlated with social conservatism. 
H8b: Dialecticism measured by the Proverb Task will be negatively correlated with economic conservatism. 
H9: Economic conservatism will negatively correlate with collectivism.
H10: If H9 is true, we expect that collectivism will account for a statistically significant amount of variance in economic conservatism-dialecticism relation. That is to say, when collectivism increases, dialecticism increases, and economic conservatism decreases.
H11: We expect that, compared to rural populations, in urban populations, the relationship between cultural thought style and political orientation will be more pronounced, as previous research suggested (Talhelm et al., 2015; Talhelm, 2018).
registration_responses.q5: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13: A total sample size of 743 is aimed for the study. However, as the data will be collected online, the number of incomplete surveys and random responders are expected to be high. Thus, we will continue to collect data until we obtain 743 participants who completed the study and correctly answered the two attention check questions.
registration_responses.q14: We determined the smallest effect size of interest as the smallest effect observed in the previous studies investigating the same effect (Talhelm et al., 2015; Talhelm, 2018), which was r = .12 (Study 1 in Talhelm, 2018). We estimated that 743 participants would be required to achieve .95 power given this effect size, for one-tail testing at .05 significance level.
registration_responses.q21: We will use α = .05. We will use one-tailed tests for H1, H3a, H3b, H4a, H5, H7, H8a, H8b, and H9.
registration_responses.q22: Participants who do not complete the survey and who give the incorrect response to any of the two attention check questions will be excluded from the analyses.
registration_responses.q23: There will be no missing data as only data from participants with complete responses will be analyzed.
registration_responses.q24:
To examine holism as a latent construct, we will conduct a SEM analysis. We will include 5 subscales of the AHS (2 for Contradiction: the original Midway items and the newly added Tolerance of Contradictions items), the Proverb Task, and The Triad Task as the indicators of holism. 

Also, to investigate the possibility that taxonomic responses on the Triad Task take more effort than thematic responses (thus, associated with reflective thinking), response times for taxonomic and thematic responses will be compared. Dependent samples t-test will be conducted on participants' average response times for their taxonomic and thematic responses.

registration_responses.q8.question: We have a correlational research design.
registration_responses.q12.question:
Participants will be recruited through a web link posted on Bogazici University student groups on social media. Participation will be compensated by right to participate in a lottery by which 250 TL gift vouchers will be given to 3 participants. All participants will be older than 18 years old and native Turkish speakers. 

If we cannot reach the attempted number of participants in this way, we will send the survey link to students enrolled in introductory psychology courses. 

As a last resort, we will share the survey link on our personal accounts and collect additional data from community sample.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Cultural thought style will be assessed by three different measures. 

First, a modified version of the TCT (Ji, Zhang, & Nisbett, 2004). Modifications were done based on a pilot study (N = 62) according to which each triad was selected while making sure that both the taxonomic and thematic relations can be recognized by the majority, that taxonomically related items do not also connote any thematic relations and that thematically bound items are not perceived as examples of the same category in any sense. Pictures of the selected triads were standardized, paying attention to prevent any two items in a triad from being visually similar to influence response patterns. All pictures were transformed into monochrome. Participants will be presented with one target item and two other items -one taxonomically and the other thematically related to the target- and be asked to choose the one which is most closely related to the target item. Taxonomic pairings are associated with an analytic thinking style and thematic pairings with holistic thinking style. 

Second, a proverb task (Peng & Nisbett, 1999) will be used to assess preferences for dialectical versus non-dialectical proverbs. The proverbs were selected among the ones used by Peng and Nisbett (1999), by Friedman, Chen, and Vid (2006) and additional Turkish proverbs which emphasize dialecticism/non-dialecticism. The selection was made based on content (whether the emphasis on dialecticism or its opposite is clear enough) by three independent coders. For each proverb, ratings of familiarity, frequency of use and poeticality will be used as control variables. In this task consisting of 16 proverbs (8 dialectical), participants will be asked to rate how much they like each proverb and how much they agree with each proverb on a 7-point scale. Proverb lists used in our first study and that will be used in this study can be found in the Files section of the project.

Finally, the Analysis-Holism Scale (AHS; Choi, Koo, & Choi, 2007) as a self-report measure for cultural thought styles will be administered. The AHS consists of four subscales (causality, attitude toward contradiction, perception of change and locus of attention) with 6 items each on a 7-point Likert-type scale (1 = completely disagree, 7 = completely agree). We will use the version we used in our first study, with additional items we wrote.

In order to test the proposed relationship between holistic thinking and other cognitive variables previously studied in political psychology literature, the Multiple Stimulus Types Ambiguity Tolerance Scale-II (MSTAT-II; McLain, 2009) will be given. This scale is a 7-point Likert-type scale consisting of 13 items.

To test the presumptive trifold relationship between holism, collectivism, and
economic liberalism, the Relational-Interdependent Self-Construal (RISC; Cross, Bacon & Morris, 2000) Scale—previously translated and validated in Turkish (Öztürk, Gökoğlu, & Karagonlar, 2015)—will be included. 

To measure analytic cognitive style as defined by the dual process model of the mind, we will use two versions of the Cognitive Reflection Test (CRT-I and CRT-II; Frederick, 2005; Thomson & Oppenheimer, 2016). The first consists of 3 and the second 4 logic questions and score on these tests are calculated by the total number of correct responses. 

Political ideology will be measured by a version of the Scale of Social Conservatism -originally created by Henningham (1996) for the Australian culture and adapted to American culture by Piazza and Landy (2013)- revised by Yılmaz and Sarıbay (2016) to adapt to Turkish politics. The scale consists of 14 items each concerning a social issue (legalization of marijuana, gay marriage etc.) to which responses range from -5 (strongly against) to +5 (not at all against). 

Economic conservatism will be measured by the Economic Conservatism Scale originated by Yılmaz and Sarıbay (2016), consisting of 16 items on a 7-point scale (1 = completely disagree, 7 = completely agree). Sample items are "The government should not interfere in the economics" and "The government should collect higher taxes from the rich and lower taxes from the poor to reduce income equality". 

Finally, in demographic form, participants will be asked several demographic questions such as their gender, age, ethnicity, education, socioeconomic status (SES), hometown, hometown size, religious affiliation, and religiosity. SES will be measured by the MacArthur Scale of Subjective Social Status (Adler, Epel, Castellazzo, & Ickovics, 2000) in which participants are asked to indicate their relative place in the society on an image of a ladder of 10 steps. Religiosity will be measured by single item asking participants the extent to which they feel religious on a scale of 1 (not at all religious) to 7 (highly religious). Also, political ideology will be measured by a single item scale ranging from 1 (very liberal) to 7 (very conservative). 

In addition, we have 2 attention check questions ("Please respond to this question as "I completely disagree" and "I have never drunk water in my life"), one within the AHS and the other in the Economic Conservatism Scale.
registration_responses.q18.question:
We will use the combination of CRT and CRT-2 scores (the sum of the correct responses to the two) as the main measure of analytic cognitive style. We will also conduct analyses with separate CRT and CRT-2 scores and with average scores instead of the sum (to avoid potential bias resulting from the unanswered questions), to check whether the results change.  

We will calculate the holistic thinking score by extracting the number of taxonomic pairings from the number of thematic pairings in the TCT. We will use this score in the correlational analyses involving the TCT. 

For the dialecticism score, we will use the combination of the revised Change subscale (original and added items) and the new Contradiction subscale (only added items emphasizing Tolerance of Contradictions) of the AHS.

In the Proverb Task, in addition to liking rates which previous research used (Peng & Nisbett, 1999), we will also use the ratings of agreement with each proverb. As liking rates can be affected by lots of other things that we cannot control, we think that agreement might provide more reliable results.
registration_responses.q19.question:
All the analyses involving the TCT will be conducted both with the traditional scoring and binomial-linked generalized linear model (see Talhelm et al. 2015; Talhelm, 2018). 

The relationship between the performance on the Triad Task and social and economic conservatism will be analyzed with separate correlations and binomial-linked GLMs. These analysis will be conducted using both the scales for social and economic conservatism and the single item political orientation scale (H1 & H2).

As H2 predicts "no relationship", an equivalence test will be conducted for the correlation between holism measured by the Triad Task and economic conservatism.

The correlation between scores on the combined dialecticism subscale of the AHS and social and economic conservatism will be examined (H3a & H3b). 

Relationship between the CRT scores and holism measured by the Triad Task will be analyzed with correlation and binomial-linked GLM (H4a).

Hierarchical regression models will be tested to investigate how much of the variance in the relationship between the Triad Task scores and conservatism is accounted for by the AHS and the CRT. It is hypothesized that the variance accounted for by the CRT scores will be larger than that by the AHS scores in the relationship between the holism scores from the Triad Task and social conservatism (H4b). 

Correlational analysis will be conducted between ambiguity tolerance (MSTAT-II) and dialecticism (H5).

Hierarchical regressions will be conducted with the combined dialecticism subscale of the AHS as the outcome and the social conservatism as the predictor in the first step, and scores on the MSTAT-II as the predictor in the second step. If the relationship between the dialecticism and conservatism can be explained by ambiguity tolerance as we hypothesized, the scores on the MSTAT-II should account for a statistically significant amount of variance explained by conservatism (H6). 

We will check the partial correlation between the liking rates for dialectical proverbs and scores on the combined dialecticism subscale of the AHS controlling for the liking rates for non-dialectical proverbs, ratings of familiarity, poeticality, and the frequency of use (H7). If the proverb task measures dialectical thinking tendency, proverb ratings should correlate with AHS scores. If so, we will conduct the same analysis with social (H8a) and economic conservatism (H8b) as the outcome instead of AHS scores. 

For the economic conservatism, two additional correlational analyses will be conducted. First, we will examine whether economic liberalism is related to collectivism as suggested above (H9). For this purpose, a correlational analysis will be conducted between economic conservatism and RISC scores. If the expected relationship is observed, we will check the partial correlation between dialecticism and economic conservatism controlling for the RISC scores (H10). 

The relationship between the holistic scores on the Triad Task and social conservatism will also be analyzed separately for participants raised in urban and rural settlements. We will categorize settlements as urban and rural based on the newly included “hometown” item which asks directly where each participant is from, as well as the hometown size question used in the first study. Hence, we will use three different criteria for urban-rural distinction: (1) Categorizing “metropolis” as urban and the rest as rural based on the hometown size question, (2) population size, and (3) population density based on the open-ended hometown question relying on the data obtained from Turkish Statistical Institute (TÜİK). Criteria 2 and 3 will be treated as continuous moderators (H11). 


Analyses examining the relationship between thought styles (analytic vs. holistic) and political orientation will also be conducted controlling for age, gender, childhood SES, religiosity and hometown size.

attributes.title: Goal conflict
attributes.description:
The Current Research
A few studies to date have addressed goal conflict in relation to individual and relational well-being showing that goal conflict has a negative impact on well-being (Gere & Impett, 2018; Gere & Schimmack, 2013; Gere et al., 2011; Righetti et al., 2016). However, surprisingly little research has been dedicated to addressing how goal conflict influences support toward goal pursuit and engagement in life’s opportunities (see Gere & Impett, 2018 and Hui et al., 2014 for exceptions). The purpose of the current research is to address this gap in the literature. Specifically, the aim of the research is to examine whether goal conflict influences the interpersonal processes of RC support: support seeking, support providing, perceived partner responsiveness, and commitment toward opportunities. We expect that goal conflict will be negatively associated with all four core processes as partners are motivated to avoid threats to the relationship. Specifically, we expect that target’s perception of goal conflict will be negatively associated with support seeking (H1; replication of research by Righetti, Kumashiro, and Campbell, 2014 using the same dataset by), perceived partner responsiveness (H2; novel), and goal commitment/motivation (H3; novel). We also expect that partner’s perception of goal conflict will be negatively associated with support providing (H4). Previous research has shown that goal conflict is associated with motivation to provide, or not provide, support (Feeney et al., 2013, 2017) but has not been tested for actual support. We do not make any a priori predictions for partner effects as there is not enough prior research to be confident about specific hypotheses. However, if anything, the associations are likely to also be negative. 
Furthermore, we also extend the current literature by addressing whether individual differences in attachment styles moderate the relationship between goal conflict and the support processes. We expect that when goal conflict is high, higher levels of attachment anxiety will negatively predict perception of support (H5) as well as motivation toward goal pursuit (H6). We expect that when goal conflict is high, individuals higher (vs. lower) in attachment avoidance will seek less support (H7). Furthermore, while individuals lower (vs. higher) in attachment avoidance will be less motivated to pursue goals, those higher in attachment avoidance will be unaffected and therefore we expect this association to be positive (H8). We also expect that when partners high (vs. low) in attachment anxiety perceive goals as conflicting, they will provide less support (H9). We expect all other moderator effects to be non-significant but include them in the model as controls. Please see Table 1 for the hypotheses and Figure 2 for a graphical illustration of the proposed predictions.
We aim to test the hypotheses in a sample of couples who completed 8-days of daily diary data. We will use multilevel modeling with two-levels of random variation in which partners are nested within dyads and days are crossed within partners (Kenny, Kashy, & Cook, 2006). We will include both partners’ perceptions of goal conflict and both partners’ attachment styles (and moderation) predicting a) support seeking, b) support providing, c) perceived responsiveness, and d) goal pursuit/movement. Furthermore, because goals can conflict with either the partner’s goals or the relationship’s goals, we will also test the models separately for goal conflict with partner’s goals and goal conflict with relationship’s goals to see whether models vary for the two outcome variables. We will also test for lagged effects by including yesterday’s goal conflict to predict the next day’s outcomes.

Secondary Data Analysis Preregistration

Title: Attachment Styles, Goal Conflict, and Relational Catalyst Support

Authors: Laura M. Vowels, Katherine B. Carnelley. Madoka Kumashiro, Angela C. Rowe

Research Questions

RQ1: Is goal conflict associated with interpersonal processes of relational catalyst support (support seeking, support providing, perceived partner responsiveness, and commitment toward opportunities)?
RQ2: Do attachment styles moderate the association between goal conflict and relational catalyst support processes?

Hypotheses and/or Estimates

For RQ1:
We expect that goal conflict will be negatively associated with all four core processes as partners are motivated to avoid threats to the relationship. Specifically, we expect that targets’ perception of goal conflict will be negatively associated with support seeking (Hypothesis 1 (H1); replication of research by Righetti, Kumashiro, and Campbell, 2014 using the same dataset by), perceived partner responsiveness (H2; novel), and goal pursuit/movement (H3; novel). We also expect that partner’s perception of goal conflict will be negatively associated with support providing (H4). Previous research has shown that goal conflict is associated with motivation to provide, or not provide, support (Feeney et al., 2013, 2017) but has not been tested for actual support. We do not make any a priori predictions for partner effects as there is not enough prior research to be confident about specific hypotheses. However, if anything, the associations are likely to also be negative. 

For RQ2:
Furthermore, we also extend the current literature by addressing whether individual differences in attachment styles moderate the relationship between goal conflict and the support processes. We expect that when goal conflict is high, higher levels of attachment anxiety will negatively predict perception of support (H5) as well as motivation toward goal pursuit (H6). We expect that when goal conflict is high, individuals higher (vs. lower) in attachment avoidance will seek less support (H7). Furthermore, while individuals lower (vs. higher) in attachment avoidance will be less motivated to pursue goals, those higher in attachment avoidance will be unaffected and therefore we expect this association to be positive (H8). We also expect that when partners high (vs. low) in attachment anxiety perceive goals as conflicting, they will provide less support (H9). We expect all other moderator effects to be non-significant but include them in the model as controls.

Other Lab Collection - Data were collected by another researcher’s lab (analysts were not involved in data collection) [Option selected from a dropdown menu]

Codebook

Sampling and data collection procedures 

This can be found on the dataverse (link above). For the present study, we will use Time 3 and 8-day daily diary.

Question Title: Prior work based on the dataset

I have used this dataset for my Master’s thesis, which can be found here (https://uknowledge.uky.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1058&context=hes_etds). I have used the variables:  attachment styles, partner affirmation, movement toward the ideal self, and relationship satisfaction (DAS). These are from the longitudinal data, not daily diary.

Prior Research Activity 

I have used some of these variables before on this (sub)set of these data

Prior Knowledge current dataset

There are a number of variables that overlap between this current question and previous work. Specifically, I have read about the use of variables “attachment anxiety” and “attachment avoidance” in the publications listed below. However, the daily diary variables involved in this study have not been used previously. I have seen descriptive statistics of the demographic and attachment variables used in this study but not daily diary study.

Arriaga, X. B., Kumashiro, M., Finkel, E. J., VanderDrift, L. E., & Luchies, L. B. (2014). Filling the void: Bolstering attachment security in committed relationships. Social Psychological and Personality Science, 5, 398-406.

Registration after data cleaning, but before any main analyses

Not Applicable

Index/Indices 

Not Applicable

Question title: Transformations

We will grand mean center predictor and moderator variables in the multilevel analyses.

Data Inclusion/exclusion

All participants who have complete data at Wave 3 and at least two of the daily diary entries will be included. 

Outliers

An outlier is any data point at Level-1 or Level-2 that is more than 3 standard deviations away from the mean. If these are encountered, we will use robustlmm package in R to estimate the multilevel models with robust estimation. 

Weights

Not Applicable

Sample size

There are 139 couples who have completed wave 3. We will use all available participants.

Missing data 

We will use restricted maximum likelihood to estimate the models, which uses all available data to estimate intercepts and slopes.

Statistical models

We will use multilevel modeling with two-levels of random variation in which partners are nested within dyads and days are crossed within partners (Kenny, Kashy, & Cook, 2006). We will include both partners’ perceptions of goal conflict (both goal conflict with partner and goal conflict with relationship) and both partners’ attachment styles (and moderation) predicting a) support seeking, b) support providing, c) perceived responsiveness, and d) goal pursuit/movement. We will report the results with and without attachment styles. We will also test for lagged effects by including yesterday’s goal conflict to predict the next day’s outcomes in separate analyses.

Follow-up analyses 

No follow-up analyses

Inference criteria

We will run each analysis three times for each of the four outcome variables: once with only goal conflict, once with attachment also included, and once with lagged effects without attachment. Therefore, we will use a Bonferroni-corrected p-value of .004 (.05 / 12).

Sensitivity Analyses 

Not Applicable

Statistical Analysis Backup Plan

We will initially run the multilevel models with random intercepts and slopes but if these do not run, we will remove random slopes from the analyses. If the partner and relationship-related goal conflict are highly correlated (above .70), we will use a combined measure of goal conflict rather than separating the two. 

Exploratory analysis

We may address alternative explanations or potential covariates that have not been prespecified but we will report these in a separate section.

registration_responses.summary:
Secondary Data Analysis Preregistration

Title: Attachment Styles, Goal Conflict, and Relational Catalyst Support

Authors: Laura M. Vowels, Katherine B. Carnelley. Madoka Kumashiro, Angela C. Rowe

Research Questions

RQ1: Is goal conflict associated with interpersonal processes of relational catalyst support (support seeking, support providing, perceived partner responsiveness, and commitment toward opportunities)?
RQ2: Do attachment styles moderate the association between goal conflict and relational catalyst support processes?

Hypotheses and/or Estimates

For RQ1:
We expect that goal conflict will be negatively associated with all four core processes as partners are motivated to avoid threats to the relationship. Specifically, we expect that targets’ perception of goal conflict will be negatively associated with support seeking (Hypothesis 1 (H1); replication of research by Righetti, Kumashiro, and Campbell, 2014 using the same dataset by), perceived partner responsiveness (H2; novel), and goal pursuit/movement (H3; novel). We also expect that partner’s perception of goal conflict will be negatively associated with support providing (H4). Previous research has shown that goal conflict is associated with motivation to provide, or not provide, support (Feeney et al., 2013, 2017) but has not been tested for actual support. We do not make any a priori predictions for partner effects as there is not enough prior research to be confident about specific hypotheses. However, if anything, the associations are likely to also be negative. 

For RQ2:
Furthermore, we also extend the current literature by addressing whether individual differences in attachment styles moderate the relationship between goal conflict and the support processes. We expect that when goal conflict is high, higher levels of attachment anxiety will negatively predict perception of support (H5) as well as motivation toward goal pursuit (H6). We expect that when goal conflict is high, individuals higher (vs. lower) in attachment avoidance will seek less support (H7). Furthermore, while individuals lower (vs. higher) in attachment avoidance will be less motivated to pursue goals, those higher in attachment avoidance will be unaffected and therefore we expect this association to be positive (H8). We also expect that when partners high (vs. low) in attachment anxiety perceive goals as conflicting, they will provide less support (H9). We expect all other moderator effects to be non-significant but include them in the model as controls.

Name or brief description of data set(s): 

Rusbult dataset from National Science Foundation, description of the dataset can be found on the Love Consortium Dataverse: https://dataverse.unc.edu/dataset.xhtml?persistentId=doi:10.15139/S3/GNBYN5 

Is this data open or publically available? No

How can the data be accessed? Provide link if available online: The data can be accessed by contacting Dr. Madoka Kumashiro or Dr. Eli Finkel

Date of download or access: Have not accessed yet.

Data Source

Other Lab Collection - Data were collected by another researcher’s lab (analysts were not involved in data collection) [Option selected from a dropdown menu]

Codebook

Codebook can be accessed via the Love Consortium Dataverse (link above).

Sampling and data collection procedures 

This can be found on the dataverse (link above). For the present study, we will use Time 3 and 8-day daily diary.

Question Title: Prior work based on the dataset

I have used this dataset for my Master’s thesis, which can be found here (https://uknowledge.uky.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1058&context=hes_etds). I have used the variables:  attachment styles, partner affirmation, movement toward the ideal self, and relationship satisfaction (DAS). These are from the longitudinal data, not daily diary.

Prior Research Activity 

I have used some of these variables before on this (sub)set of these data

Prior Knowledge current dataset

There are a number of variables that overlap between this current question and previous work. Specifically, I have read about the use of variables “attachment anxiety” and “attachment avoidance” in the publications listed below. However, the daily diary variables involved in this study have not been used previously. I have seen descriptive statistics of the demographic and attachment variables used in this study but not daily diary study.

Arriaga, X. B., Kumashiro, M., Finkel, E. J., VanderDrift, L. E., & Luchies, L. B. (2014). Filling the void: Bolstering attachment security in committed relationships. Social Psychological and Personality Science, 5, 398-406.

Moment of preregistration

Registration after data cleaning, but before any main analyses

attributes.title: Physical Activity and Covid-19
attributes.description: This study aims to understand what individual difference factors influence physical activity engagement in the midst of a pandemic.

q2.value:
H1: We hypothesize that participants with greater social support will report greater physical activity competence, and greater intrinsic motivation for physical activity, which will predict greater engagement in physical activity.

H2: We hypothesize that participants who report greater physical activity will report fewer symptoms of depression, anxiety and stress during the shelter-in-place (T1 and T2) and after it is lifted (T3).

H3: We will examine the extent to which greater use of technology to connect with others (e.g., social media, videochats, voice calls, texting) is associated with greater engagement in physical activity and less symptoms of depression, anxiety and stress. We hypothesize that greater use of video chatting and voice calls will be more strongly and negatively associated with depression, anxiety and stress compared to social media and texting use. 

Exploratory hypothesis: We will explore whether physical activity social support mediates the relationship between technology use (social media, videochats, voice calls, texting) and physical activity.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is a single group, repeated measures design in which participants will complete self-report measures at three timepoints (spaced 4 weeks apart: baseline, 4 weeks, and 8 weeks). This is a completely within-subjects design.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Population: students, faculty and staff from Rosalind Franklin University of Medicine & Science
Eligibility criteria: 
    Inclusion criteria: Adults age 18 years or older; RFUMS student, staff or faculty
    Exclusion criteria: Current physical activity restrictions
Participants will be recruited via emails sent by an administrator not affiliated with the study.
Participants will receive a $5 giftcard for completing each of the three assessments for a total of $15.

q12.value:
300 was selected for several reasons.
300 was consistent with the limited funds available for data collection.
300 was feasible to recruit in one month time given the time-sensitive nature of the study and the limited population from which we are recruiting.
Since this is a longitudinal study, we anticipate missing data. We will attempt to keep missing data to less than 20% with incomplete data at a single timepoint. if 20% are missing data at a later time point, we would still have a sample of 240 with at least two timepoints of data.
Aim 1: With a sample of 240, > 80% power to detect a medium effect (0.30) for a model with 3 latent variables and 7 manifest variables. Underpowered to detect a small effect

Aim 2: With a sample of 240, > 80% power to detect partial r2 = 0.035 for a model with one predictor and 4 potential covariates.

Aim 3: With a sample of 240, > 80% power to detect partial r2 = 0.05 for a model with four predictors and 4 potential covariates.

Aim 4: Exploratory. No power analysis completed.

q13.value: Recruitment will end prior to enrolling 300 participants, if the shelter-in-place order is lifted.

question.value: None. Observational study.

Physical activity restriction. This question will only be completed at time 1 to ensure that the participant meets inclusion criteria.

Demographics: age, gender, race/ethnicity, education, number of people living in household, number of children, diagnosis of a chronic health condition. Demographics will only be completed at time 1.

Participants will be asked about whether they or someone they know has or had covid-19.

Self-reported weight and height. Participants will be asked to self-report their height and weight. 

Physical activity. The Global Physical Activity Scale will be used to measure self-reported physical activity. Participants will also answer a single question that has them identify whether their physical activity amount has changed since the shelter-in-place order. This single question will only be asked during the time 1 survey.  

Physical activity competence. The Perceived Competence Scale (PCS) concerns feelings about behaving in healthy ways. This is a short 4-item questionnaire that assesses the degree to which participants feel conﬁdent about being able to make (or maintain) a change in physical activity.

Physical activity Social support. This 13 item-scale measures social support from family and friends for physical activity. The measure contains three, factor-derived subscales: Family Participation, Family Rewards and Punishment and Friend Participation

Exercise self-regulation questionnaire. This questionnaire concerns the reasons why a person exercises regularly‚ does gymnastics‚ works out‚ or engages in other such physical activities. It is structured so that it asks one questions and provides responses that represent external regulation‚ introjected regulation‚ identified regulation‚ and intrinsic motivation. The basic issue concerns the degree to which one feels autonomous with respect to exercising or engaging in physical activity.

Exercise identity scale. This 9-item scale by Anderson and Cychosz (1994) will be used to assess the extent to which participants view exercise as integral to their self-concept. 

Depressive symptoms. The PROMIS Short Form v1.0 - Depression is an 8-item measure that assess symptoms of depression.

Anxiety symptoms. The PROMIS Short Form v1.0 - Anxiety is an 8-item scale that assesses symptoms of anxiety.

Perceived stress scale: This 10-item scale measures the degree to which situations in one’s life are appraised as stressful. Items were designed to tap how unpredictable, uncontrollable, and overloaded respondents find their lives.

Technology use: Questions based on the PEW internet survey will ask participants to report the amount of time they are spending using 4 different types of technologies to connect with others. The 4 questions assess use of social media, video-chatting, text-messaging, and voice calls.

Validity questions. There are three questions embedded throughout the survey to ensure that participants are not responding randomly to questions. In these questions, participants are asked to provide a specific response (e.g., Select not at all for this question).

See included file for more detail:
H1: We hypothesize that participants with greater social support will report greater physical activity competence, and greater intrinsic motivation for physical activity, which will predict greater engagement in physical activity.
•	Structural equation modeling. Fit indices will be used to determine model fit. 
•	Proposed model: Social support (time 1 and time 2) will be associated with physical activity competence (time 1 and time 2), which will be associated with intrinsic motivation for physical activity (time 1 and time 2), which will predict physical activity (3 timepoints).
H2: We hypothesize that participants who report greater physical activity will report fewer symptoms of depression, anxiety and stress during the shelter-in-place (T1 and T2) and after it is lifted (T3).
•	3 separate mixed models: one for each DV (random intercept likely included, if AIC fit index is improved with random intercept included).

H3: We will examine the extent to which greater use of technology to connect with others (e.g., social media, videochats, voice calls, texting) is associated with greater engagement in physical activity and less symptoms of depression, anxiety and stress. We hypothesize that greater use of video chatting and voice calls will be more strongly and negatively associated with depression, anxiety and stress compared to social media and texting use. 
•	4 separate mixed models: one for each DV (random intercept likely included, if AIC fit index is improved with random intercept included).

Aim 4: We will explore whether physical activity social support mediates the relationship between technology use (social media, videochats, voice calls, texting) and physical activity.  
•	Path Analysis: Fit indices will be used to determine model fit. 
•	Proposed model: Time 1 time spent using social media, videochats, voice calls, texting (each a separate predictor) predicts time 2 physical activity social support, which predicts time 3 physical activity.

q19.value:
For structural equation modeling, the following fit indices will be used:	The model chi-square (p> .05), RMSEA (< .08), AGFI (≥0.90), CFI (≥0.90), SRMR (<.08).

For mixed models, p <.05 will be used.

q20.value:
There are three validity check questions in each survey. Participants who do not answer those questions correctly will have their data from that particular survey excluded from analyses. 

Preliminary analyses will include boxplots to check for outliers.

q21.value: We will conduct a missing data analysis to examine whether data are missing at random. Estimated and actual values will be compared. Little's MCAR test will be conducted. If missing data appears to be random, then multiple imputation will be used for missing data.

attributes.title: An umbrella review of psychological interventions aimed at the prevention and treatment of mental and psychosocial problems of college students
attributes.description:
The college years are a developmentally crucial period for young people in which they make the transition from late adolescence to emerging adulthood (Arnett, 2000). Psychosocial and mental health problems during this phase of life are not only highly prevalent (Auerbach et al., 2018), but they also affect academic functioning (Bruffaerts, 2018) and can have long-term adverse outcomes in later adulthood, including persistent emotional and physical health problems, relationship dysfunction, and labor market marginalization (Scott, 2016; Kerr, 2011). Moreover, a problematic start of the professional career can have long-term negative consequences for career success and sustainability (Niederkrotenthaler, 2015; Akkermans, 2018).
Many psychological interventions for these problems in college students have been developed and tested in randomized controlled trials, and a considerable number of meta-analyses of these trials have been published. However, because the field is so large, there is no good overview of interventions and the randomized trials available for this field. 
The goal of the current umbrella review of meta-analyses is to provide an overview of the field, including the number and quality of trials, the focus of the trials, the interventions, and the effect sizes found for the interventions in the meta-analyses. We also rate the quality of the included meta-analyses.

q2.value: We have no specific hypothesis for this umbrella review.

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q5.value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We will search for meta-analyses of randomized trials, focused on college or university students for prevention or treatment of any psychosocial or mental health problem. We will only include meta-analyses that report effect sizes (standardized mean difference), and that have included at least 5 randomized trials. We will include meta-analyses which have included studies that are controlled but not randomized, if they report the results separately for randomized and non-randomized trials, or if 75% or more of the trials is randomized. We will also include meta-analyses of trials that are not exclusively focused on college students, but only if they report effect sizes separately for college students or 75% or more of the trials are focused on college students.

q7.value: Because we will not conduct a randomised trial, but a meta-analysis, we will not randomise.

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q9.value: We will not use existing data, but will collect all relevant data from the published meta-analyses

question.value:
Searches will be conducted in PubMed, PsycInfo and the Cochrane database of randomized trials.
The records that are identified through the searches are read by two independent reviewers, all records that are identified by one of the reviewers as a study that could potentially meet inclusion criteria, will be retrieved in full-text. Full text papers will be read by two independent reviewers and disagreements about inclusion will be solved by discussion. Extracted effect sizes will also be assessed by two independent reviewers.

q11.value: It is not clear in advance how many studies will be included because this is an umbrella review

q12.value: Because this is a meta-analysis, we have to work with the existing, available data

q13.value: A stopping rule cannot be used in this project, because this is a meta-analytic project

question.value:
We will collect the following data:
For each meta-analysis we will collect the PICO (participants, intervention, comparison group, outcome), the pooled effect size and 95% CI for each PICO, the level of heterogeneity (I-square with 95% CI; if the 95% CI is not reported we will calculate it based on the value of the Chi-square and degrees of freedom, with the Heterogi module in STATA).
We will collect the references of the primary studies that are included in the meta-analyses, so that we can examine the overlap between studies included in the meta-analyses, and the proportion of unique studies in each meta-analysis. This also gives an overview of the total number of studies in the whole field and subfields. 
For the primary studies included in the meta-analyses, we will also extract the quality assessment that is given in the meta-analyses. Because many different instruments are used to assess the quality or risk of bias of trials, we will transform the quality score to a proportion: the quality rating will be transformed to a score between 0 and 1, which will allow to retrieve comparable ratings across meta-analyses. If the quality of one primary study is rated by two meta-analyses, we will select the lowest quality score. This procedure will allow us to get an overview of the quality of the total number of included studies. 
Finally, we will rate the quality of all included studies with the AMSTAR-2 instrument.

- effect size for each PICO with 95% CI, I-square and 95% CI 
- number of included primary studies in each meta-analysis
- total number of primary studies in all meta-analyses
- proportion of unique primary studies in each meta-analyses
- quality of all included primary studies (on a scale between 0 and 1)
- quality of the included meta-analyses (all aspects of AMSTAR-2).
We will not pool individual effect sizes, because this is a systematic review and pooling is not possible across meta-analyses.
No new analyses will be done, only simple counting of numbers (see paragraph on ‘Measured variables’)

registration_responses.q6.question: We will search for meta-analyses of randomized trials, focused on college or university students for prevention or treatment of any psychosocial or mental health problem. We will only include meta-analyses that report effect sizes (standardized mean difference), and that have included at least 5 randomized trials. We will include meta-analyses which have included studies that are controlled but not randomized, if they report the results separately for randomized and non-randomized trials, or if 75% or more of the trials is randomized. We will also include meta-analyses of trials that are not exclusively focused on college students, but only if they report effect sizes separately for college students or 75% or more of the trials are focused on college students.
registration_responses.q10.question:
Searches will be conducted in PubMed, PsycInfo and the Cochrane database of randomized trials.
The records that are identified through the searches are read by two independent reviewers, all records that are identified by one of the reviewers as a study that could potentially meet inclusion criteria, will be retrieved in full-text. Full text papers will be read by two independent reviewers and disagreements about inclusion will be solved by discussion. Extracted effect sizes will also be assessed by two independent reviewers.
registration_responses.q14.question:
We will collect the following data:
For each meta-analysis we will collect the PICO (participants, intervention, comparison group, outcome), the pooled effect size and 95% CI for each PICO, the level of heterogeneity (I-square with 95% CI; if the 95% CI is not reported we will calculate it based on the value of the Chi-square and degrees of freedom, with the Heterogi module in STATA).
We will collect the references of the primary studies that are included in the meta-analyses, so that we can examine the overlap between studies included in the meta-analyses, and the proportion of unique studies in each meta-analysis. This also gives an overview of the total number of studies in the whole field and subfields. 
For the primary studies included in the meta-analyses, we will also extract the quality assessment that is given in the meta-analyses. Because many different instruments are used to assess the quality or risk of bias of trials, we will transform the quality score to a proportion: the quality rating will be transformed to a score between 0 and 1, which will allow to retrieve comparable ratings across meta-analyses. If the quality of one primary study is rated by two meta-analyses, we will select the lowest quality score. This procedure will allow us to get an overview of the quality of the total number of included studies. 
Finally, we will rate the quality of all included studies with the AMSTAR-2 instrument.

- effect size for each PICO with 95% CI, I-square and 95% CI 
- number of included primary studies in each meta-analysis
- total number of primary studies in all meta-analyses
- proportion of unique primary studies in each meta-analyses
- quality of all included primary studies (on a scale between 0 and 1)
- quality of the included meta-analyses (all aspects of AMSTAR-2).

attributes.title: A systematic mapping review of effective preoperative education interventions for engaging and providing information to patients undergoing ambulatory surgery

summary.value:
Significant progress in anaesthetic and surgical practices has led to the development of ambulatory surgery, defined as the absence of overnight accommodation for those being treated the night after their surgery. More than half of all surgical operations in France are now performed on an outpatient basis. However, the efficiency of ambulatory surgery is based on the increased responsibility of the patient during his or her care, particularly in the preoperative period and during postoperative rehabilitation.
Preoperative psychological preparation is therefore essential to enable the patient to be aware of the different stages of his care. In this context, the quality of preoperative information is decisive for the success of the ambulatory care pathway, as it contributes to the patient experience.
It is therefore essential to evaluate the effectiveness of preoperative information systems for people treated in outpatient surgery, although no studies have been found on this subject.
The objective of this work is therefore to identify and synthesize, with a systematic mapping review, the evidence of the effectiveness of preoperative information delivered to patients who should undergo ambulatory surgery.
The results obtained from this review will help to guide the conduct of other studies constituting the ADON research program, focusing on the consequences of preoperative information on the outpatients’ engagement.
